name: Pregnancy in Marfan Syndrome
description: Pregnancy in Marfan syndrome carries significant cardiovascular risks, primarily aortic dissection. Risk stratification is based on pre-pregnancy aortic root diameter, with the threshold generally set at 4.0-4.5 cm. Multidisciplinary management involving cardiology, maternal-fetal medicine, anesthesiology, and cardiovascular surgery is essential. Careful pre-pregnancy counseling, aggressive medical management, and planned delivery are critical components of care.

hemodynamic_changes.blood_pressure: Typically decreases in first trimester, rises in third

cardiac_evaluation.echocardiography: Detailed aortic root and ascending aorta measurements
cardiac_evaluation.mri: If echo images suboptimal or more distal aorta assessment needed

genetic_counseling.inheritance: 50% chance of passing Marfan to offspring
genetic_counseling.options: IVF with preimplantation genetic diagnosis, adoption, surrogacy
genetic_counseling.testing: Partner testing for FBN1 if family history

surgical_consideration.prophylactic_surgery: Consider root replacement before conception if 4.0-4.5 cm

discussion_topics: Risk of aortic dissection during/after pregnancy

beta_blockers.agents: Metoprolol or labetalol preferred (more data in pregnancy)

arbs_ace_inhibitors.status: STOP before conception or immediately upon pregnancy confirmation

echocardiography.more_frequent: If growth detected or diameter near threshold

activity_restriction.exercise: Mild activity acceptable, avoid isometric exercise

timing.earlier_delivery: Consider if rapid aortic growth or symptoms

vaginal.consideration: Acceptable if aortic root <40mm and stable

indications: Prior aortic surgery (consider based on surgery type)

anesthesia.epidural: Recommended to minimize pain and hemodynamic stress

delivery_planning.facility: Delivery at center with cardiovascular surgery capability

acute_dissection_during_pregnancy.presentation: Severe chest/back pain - maintain high suspicion
acute_dissection_during_pregnancy.imaging: Echocardiography (no radiation), MRI if stable (avoid gadolinium in 1st trimester), CT if unstable

type_a_dissection.fetal_consideration: Cesarean delivery if viable gestation, then aortic repair

postpartum_considerations.continued_risk: Dissection risk remains elevated for 6-12 months postpartum

medication.breastfeeding: Metoprolol and propranolol compatible with breastfeeding

postpartum_considerations.surveillance: Continue imaging at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months postpartum
postpartum_considerations.contraception: Discuss effective contraception to avoid unplanned pregnancy

clinical_pearls: Aortic root >4.0-4.5 cm = consider prophylactic surgery BEFORE pregnancy
Third trimester and early postpartum are highest risk periods for dissection
